_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



Certification Letter



The Hawkeye Gas Facility (HGF) is a new facility replacing an older compressor station.  The facility compresses produced gas and removes water vapor, collects NGL (Natural Gas Liquids) and sends the NGL and compressed gas to the Tioga Gas Facility via pipeline.  The Hawkeye Gas Facility processes flammable gas and liquids which contain the toxic compound hydrogen sulfide (H2S) at less than the threshold quantity.



A study was performed using the BakerRisk's  SafeSite 3G computer code  and the Baker-Strehlow-Tang methodology to determine the 1-psi overpressure impact of a vapor cloud explosion.  The worst-case scenario was determined to be the filling of the compressor building with flammable gas release from the flash gas compressor. The flash gas compressor inventory of 10,821 lbs. is greater than the required stoichiometric volume of 7,460 lbs.  to fill the compressor building with a stoichiometric fuel-air cloud. A resulting vapor cloud explosion (VCE) would produce a 1-psi overpressure at 0.13 miles which could impact a public receptor. This worst-case overpressure case with a potential impact to a public receptor, results in the Hawkeye Gas Facility being subject to EPA RMP Program level 3.  The facility is also subject to OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals. 



This is a new facility and therefore there have been no accidental releases during the last five years with an offsite consequence as defined by the Risk Management Program rule 40 CFR 68.10(b)(1).  This facility complies with applicable environmental requirements administered by EPA and it is the company policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local laws.  No additional measures are necessary to prevent offsite impacts of accidental releases.  



In the event of fire, explosion, or a release of a regulated substance from the process, our facility has Emergency Response Plan in place and our facility

personnel have been trained in emergency response. It is our company policy to notify the 911 and/or Keene Volunteer Fire Department and request they respond to the emergency.  Entry within the distance to the specified endpoints may pose a danger to the local volunteer fire department and other emergency responders. Therefore, the local volunteer fire department and other emergency responders should not enter this area except as arranged with the emergency contact indicated in the RMP.



The undersigned certifies that, to the best of my knowledge, information, and belief formed after reasonable inquiry, the information submitted is true, accurate and complete.



 

Michael Bast

Director, Midstream Operations







ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES



The Hawkeye Gas Facility, which is owned and operated by Hess North Dakota Pipelines, LLC, has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the investment of significant resources in accident prevention, such as personnel training, mechanical inspection, process control systems and by recognition of safety as a primary factor in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our processes. However, if an accidental release does occur, trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release if safe to do so.



The Hawkeye Gas Facility controls its hazardous materials by: 

?    A commitment to OSHA's PSM and HAZWOPER standards, EPA's RMP, and the Department of Transportation's Hazardous Materials Transportation Act regulations which promote and require adherence to process safety activities designed to prevent accidental releases.



?    Use of the parent company Hess Corporation and the Hawkeye Gas Facility safety, operating, maintenance, emergency response, engineering design and construction policies, procedures and practices designed to prevent accidents and potential releases. 



?    A knowledge of and adherence to applicable industry

recognized standards, specifications and recommended practices that address and provide guidance for the proper design, construction, operation and maintenance of facilities containing hazardous materials. 



?    A comprehensive equipment inspection and testing program.



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The Hawkeye Gas Facility, located at 10394 43rd Street NW, New Town, ND 58763 in McKenzie County, compresses produced natural gas and removes the water vapor, collects NGL (Natural Gas Liquids), sends the NGL and compressed gas to the Tioga Gas Facility.  This new facility is replacing an older compressor station and has several regulated flammables, such as Methane, Ethane, Propane, Butane, Isobutane, Pentane and Natural Gas Condensate which are greater than the RMP threshold quantities.   In addition, the facility contains a by-product of Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S) which is below the RMP threshold quantity. 



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



Processes at the Hawkeye Gas Facility that are regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) regulation are also subject to the Occupational Safety & Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard. The Hawkeye Gas Facility adheres to all applicable federal and state regulatory statutes.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



This is a new facility and therefore has had no accidental release that caused off-site impacts as defined by the EPA Risk Management Program rule 40 CFR 68.10(b)(1). This facility or the older Hawkeye compressor station it is replacing, within the past 5 years the Facility has not experienced an incident involving regulated flammables that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damages, evacuations or sheltering in-place. 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION



The Hawkeye Gas Facility maintains a written emergency response program, which is designed to protect worker and public safety,

and the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to the release of regulated substances, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is involved. The procedure addresses emergency response, proper first aid and medical treatment, evacuation plans, accounting for personnel, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public. In addition, the plant has procedures that address maintenance, inspection and testing and instructions in the use of emergency response equipment. Employees received training in these procedures will perform their specific emergency response duties as required. The emergency response program will be reviewed periodically and updated when necessary based on any modifications made to the Hawkeye Gas Facility.



WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO



The Hawkeye Gas Facility identified potential candidates for worst-case scenarios and utilized the services of the Baker Engineering and Risk Consultants, Inc. of San Antonio, Texas to perform consequence analyses using BakerRisk's  SafeSite 3G computer code  and the Baker-Strehlow-Tang (BST) methodology for determining the RMP designated 1-psi overpressure contour. According to the analyses, the maximum end-point distance for a 1-psi vapor cloud explosion (VCE) is 0.13 miles from the center of the explosion, resulting from the instantaneous release of 10,821 lbs. (the flash gas compressor volume) which is greater than the required stoichiometric volume of 7,460 lbs. to produce a stoichiometric fuel-air cloud and subsequent vapor cloud explosion (VCE) inside the compressor building.  This worst-case release would affect a public receptor.  

 

ALTERNATE WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO



An alternate worst-case release scenario was identified for the Hawkeye Gas Facility which is a liquid release from the NGL Bullet Tank (D-751003) containing 26,103 lbs. of flammable hydrocarbon liquids. The maximum distance to the predicted lower flammability li

mit (LFL) boundary for the alternate release scenario is 0.05 miles. The maximum distance to the predicted 1-psi overpressure contour is 0.07 miles, this contour extends beyond the property owned and occupied by the Hawkeye Gas Facility but would not impact an identified public receptor.  



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Hawkeye Gas Facility conducts ongoing efforts to reduce risk through the Risk Management Program and Process Safety Management. These include recommendations from process hazards analyses, employee suggestions, incident investigations, compliance audits and the preventative maintenance and mechanical integrity program.
